text: it's been an amazing summer require
honest about it I had great difficulty
getting on the ballot paper as everybody
knows and eventually I got 36
nominations with less than two minutes
to go and so I was on the ballot paper
and we always felt those of us that had
decided that I would be put forward and
on to this that there was a lot of
people out there that wanted politics
done in a different way and they saw the
Labour Party is the way to achieve it
and we started by doing the hustings
events I started with the Fabian Society
hustings then the journal municipal
workers union and then eventually other
ones and we organized public events to
follow those hustings in different towns
I remember very distinctly the public
meeting we organised in Nottingham was
absolutely RAM packed in a in the art
centre there I realized then the
enthusiasm there was for doing things
differently maybe this might happen not
exactly because we were still being put
way behind in in everything but I just
felt there was an enthusiasm there there
was a lot of enthusiasm for our campaign
the style of it and the inclusion of it
because we put out 13 policy concerns on
tation proposals and people are still
responding to those and we involved a
huge number of people both returnees to
the Labour Party were probably resigned
after the Iraq war and a lot of young
people that came in but one night you
know we had a phone bank when 400 people
came to make phone calls to labour
members and supporters that's got to be
quite a big phone bank for volunteers
you won against the wishes though of the
labour establishment if you like what's
it like today at Prime Minister's
Questions for example to be there and
know that your colleagues your MPs
sitting behind you didn't think that you
were the right choice very interesting
experience and I've had some absolutely
fascinating conversations with people
ever since I was elected yes I have a
mandate that comes from members and
supporters there I was not supported by
the majority of MPs but I have to say
they've been
was respectful cooperative and we have
managed to put together a shadow cabinet
which does have a majority of women on
it and is I think you would agree a
broad range of opinion so it's going to
be some very interesting debate days
ahead but I think people have to
recognize that the thirst out there for
a different way of doing politics a
different way of doing our democracy is
something that I feel very strongly
about and is an enormous responsibility
on me to make sure it's delivered so how
long will you allow members of your
shadow cabinet to disagree with you very
publicly so for example this week we've
seen the shadow foreign secretary say
labour would never campaign to leave the
EU that's not your position or is it
well we're having discussions to sort
this question out basically on the
question of Europe I want to see a
social Europe a cohesive Europe a
coherent Europe not a free-market Europe
that is a developing position it's not a
problem we've had that discussion and
we've continuing that discussion there
will be very clear statements coming out
in the very near future don't worry
about that but in a straightforward
sense right now could you see a
situation where labour with you as
leader did campaign to leave the EU no I
don't see that position because I think
we're going to be working with trade
unions and social groups all across
Europe as well as social groups in this
country so I see the I see the way
forward as how we develop the idea of a
social Europe what I was opposed to and
remain opposed to is the idea that David
Cameron could go around Europe and give
up workers rights give up environmental
protection give up a whole lot of things
that are very important because Europe
has a interesting twin-track approach up
until Maastricht there was a growth in
the social Europe idea postmasters it's
been very much free-market economics I
want to see something different but what
happens if David Cameron comes back the
deal that you don't like
if those protections that you think are
very important do disappear in a
straightforward way can you wave if you
don't get the deal if David Cameron
doesn't get a deal that you agree with
can you see Jeremy Corbyn as leader of
the Labour Party hypothetically
campaigning
leave the EU but it's a hypothetical
question but I what I would do first of
all is strongly at home is strongly
oppose what cameron has done and say we
have to stay in europe to change those
policies and that would be a manifesto
commitment up to 2020 but we're working
this position out at the moment that's
anything though because that's a change
a very clear change so your position
that you have said previously I've said
I wouldn't give Cameron open a blank
check and I don't give him a blank check
very interesting on another subject
welfare for example your shadow cabinet
members of them have said they do
support the welfare cap do you the
welfare cap is an imposition by this
government which hurts the life chances
of a lot of poor people who receive
housing benefit to pay for exorbitant
private rented property and it's been
imposed and the effect has been social
cleansing of the central areas of many
of our cities I am opposed to that cap I
don't believe it's fair or right and I
don't believe we should reduce it either
and have a twin track cap across the
country and so I see it as being removed
so you want it to be removed members of
your shadow cabinet do not they've been
clear about that for how long will you
allow the situation to go on where it's
discussion rather than decision because
some people believe if you're at odds
with the members of your team it gives
out a message that you're not really in
charge the message is this cap is
damaging to people's life charters the
message is this cap is unfair the
message is that the government also
should consider about the amount of
money that's spent in the welfare budget
that subsidizes low wages and high rents
but on the point of disagreements with
your team voters eventually need to know
what the Labour Party would actually do
if you're in charge who is in charge is
it your policy I've been elected to lead
ivenn electively the party I want to
take people with me my whole default
position is one of discussion and
persuasion and that's the discussion and
persuasion is going on now you may say
so seem to be assumed
that I'm going to dictate everything no
I'm not I'm going to persuade people
that's what my position is but I also
would ask colleagues to recognize the
mandate that the leader of the party has
received from a much wider electorate so
in the end the final decision is yours
with that huge mandate yesterday you
didn't sing the national anthem
today we're told that you will on other
public occasions you are having to shift
on some of your principles it got look I
was at any events yesterday to
commemorate the Battle of Britain and it
was a beautiful service and it was in
supports Cathedral and I was thinking
about the sacrifices that people made my
family's generation made and this
post-war settlement from which we've all
greatly benefited I was there to show
respect for their sacrifice and respect
for it and I stood with the proper
attention as I did today when we had
groups of service people and others who
came in had been dealing with the Ebola
crisis in West Africa was it wrong not
to sing the national anthem if now you
say you will at similar events was it
wrong or disrespectful not to do so
yesterday I think it's very strange that
the only thing the majority of media are
remotely interested in is is that rather
than the importance of that occasion or
the importance of other issues within
our society it seems to me that some
people that kind of over concerned about
these things do you see why some people
do think that is important I understand
it I was at the event to show respect
and I did show respect and throughout
that event and I will continue to do so
at all the other events I attend as
leader of Her Majesty's opposition you
are now going to become a member of the
Privy Council part of this ceremony to
become a member of the Privy Council
involves kneeling before the Queen will
you do that
I haven't yet been rouen vited to join
the Privy Council dentistry says they
have but I haven't seen any letters I'm
looking forward to seeing the letter and
finding out what's involved when
uxs or are you clear you will accept the
invitation to join if it goes with the
job yes but I'm not sure it does at the
ceremony so dad let's say Daniel Street
have said you are being invited to join
the Privy Council you say you will
accept that part of that involves
kneeling before the Queen will you do
that I didn't know that was involved
actually so we'll have to find out about
it okay that isn't the ceremony that is
what is involved okay thank you thank
you well of course I'll end up being a
member of the Privy Council if that's
what the requirement of the job is I
think there are some things that ought
to change in our society maybe that's
one of them will you do that though it's
an important symbol to people who
believe in it I'm not saying for one
second whether it's the right thing with
the wrong thing to do be quite honest
it's the first time I've heard that is
part of it
so can we leave it though it's just an
interesting question I think people will
wonder what you might think of that
would you commit to doing it land can we
think about that thank you no it's not a
no I was the first I've heard of it I
want to discuss with colleagues this
whole process there has been controversy
about your shadow Chancellor's previous
praise for the IRA do you understand the
loss of people particularly given the
current crisis it's torment find some of
the new leadership positions hard to
stomach John McDonnell has been involved
in promoting the peace process in
Ireland for a very long time and it has
been very consistent on achieving that
like me he fully supports the Belfast
agreement a good friday process in the
peace process in Northern Ireland is a
huge step forward and I think we should
recognize that and I hope that the
crisis installment is resolved I hope
that the crisis is resolved by agreement
between the major parties so we continue
with the de haan principle and
appointment of the power sharing
agreement forgive me that wasn't my
question
my question was do you understand why
some members of the public have concerns
find it hard to stomach the way that you
and John McDonald have in the past
praised the Republican movement
did you understand that I have supported
the idea of bringing peace to Northern
Ireland and I think the construction of
the early days before the Good Friday
Agreement when shin Fane and the SDLP
came to agreement and then shin Fane
SDLP and the unis came to agreement in
which they recognized the different
historical past they'd had different
traditions was something that was a
great achievement it was the only way to
bring about peace because there was
never going to be a military solution in
Northern Ireland and I never wanted a
military solution I always wanted as
John did a peaceful solution and I think
we're beginning to well we're getting
there just finally you've had enormous
success in building a campaign quite new
what does success for a Jeremy Corbyn as
the Labour leader look like is this
syriza like in Greece do you see this as
a sort of popular revolt against the
Westminster establishment what's your
vision I suppose our party has grown
enormously we've recruited over 30,000
members since the end of our election
campaign on Saturday morning and that is
a big achievement we have more than half
a million people taking part in this
election process party membership and
activity going up a great deal so I see
this as development of a much more
social movement orientated Labour Party
much more involved in community activity
and community campaigns there's
something very exciting about the number
of young people that have got involved
in politics who everyone had written off
as a non-political generation in fact it
was politics that have written them off
that's what's exciting about this with
you as Prime Minister 2020 is some way
off we've got a lot of campaigning to do
we've made an incredible start we have
the biggest party membership we've had
for many many decades if not ever and
it's very very exciting
and I'm looking forward to all the
challenges ahead we've only four days
ago won this election campaign it's been
an incredibly complicated and busy four
days but I think we've achieved a number
of things we've achieved a majority
women Shadow Cabinet we've achieved a
politically balanced Shadow Cabinet
which reflects the different strands of
opinion within the parliamentary Labour
Party we've achieved a lot more party
members and I was able to address the
tea you see yesterday to assure them of
the close relationship between the
traditions of the trade unions and to
oppose the government attempt to
restrict the rights of people to
organize themselves in this country
which itself is a contravention of the
European Convention on Human Rights and
the International Labour Organization
conventions I think first four days very
busy very exciting very interesting role
on the next four years Jeremy Corbyn
thank you very much indeed
